review: After 5 hours of fooling around with this product, it is being sent back.I read 20 blogs, with about 50 things to try in order to make it work----disable IGMP, enable multicast, disable multicast, configure NAT, add Chrome to firewall exception list, disable firewall, disable AP isolation, reboot this, reboot that, stand on one foot....I was briefly able to display my laptop PC on my TV using the Chromecast device, then the screen went away.  Re-casted, only to experience the same thing.  After numerous tries, factory resets, and 3 different devices, I never was able to connect again.Seriously---what a piece of crap.  I suggest a new name for this device------ "CrapCast".
author: Steve T.

author: Robert M. Kirwan "World Traveller"

review: UPDATE: After a bit of research, I found that if you change the quality from high def to standard before casting a browser video from you computer - the video on the TV is pretty smooth and the audio is in sync.Overall, I am happy with the quality and functionality of this feature after all.I already have a Roku and Tivo which can stream, so Chromecast doesn't offer much more functionality.What you do get from Chromecast is the ability to use a phone/tablet as the remote. As far as I see - this has to be why you want it.If you buy a chromecast and wish it came with a remote, then you should just buy a Roku or blu-ray player with wifi apps.The ability to navigate on a tablet and queue up shows on the TV is the main draw here.If you think about it - when you imagine a millionaire watching TV, the remote you picture is probably similar to a large smartphone or tablet, right? So Chromecast allows you to use your expensive smartphone to enhance the TV navigation experience.For that, I think the price is just right.Netflix and youtube worked well. I tried casting video from my computer chrome browser and it did not work well.Choppy, and it really had the computer working hard to stream the video.If they figure out how to get the Chromecast to stream directly from a URL rather than streaming through your computer - they would have a real valuable feature. That is why I got it, but really for $35 - its cool enough to keep.
author: mattyj

review: I got this so we could stream netflix shows into the tvs in our young daughters' rooms. I installed the app on my Nexus and extension on my Chrome browser and had them watching a show in about 10 minutes.  We have only had it a few day but totally love it.  I'm already thinking of getting one for me to use when traveling.
author: Gregory D Cruess

review: Basically another way to access video content straight to your TV (Netflix, Youtube, Google Play music, movies, and tv shows). While current smart TVs and blu-ray players also have apps, what makes the chromecast better is that it actually uses your phone (or tablet, or pc) as the remote. So I can surf my for movies on my phone and then stream it right to the TV. Then your phone becomes the remote for whatever you are streaming. Hit pause on your phone and it pauses it on the tv.Since the content is not actually streaming From your phone, but rather just letting your TV know what to play, you can use your phones other apps while watch the video. You can even leave.And you don't need to be signed into any particular account to cast to chromecast. Anyone you allow on your wifi network can cast to the tv.And being able to cast a tab from google chrome on your computer is awesome. You can stream countless videos from the internet from there also. Also, since it is only streaming from one tab, you can open another tab and use your facebook or anything else you want without interrupting what you are casting to the tv.AMAZING for $35
